Nicholas Gao shared a post: Celebrating Outstanding Achievements at the Babel Film Awards
CIS Film students showcased their exceptional talent at the recent 2nd Babel Film Awards, clinching major honours across multiple categories. Notable wins included Best Picture for "If It Was Meant To Be" and Best Film in the After School - Secondary section for "Locked In., as well as Audience Award “The Pie Quest”. Our students also received awards for Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Editing and Best Sound Design. Competing against top programs from across Asia, our students demonstrated remarkable creativity and dedication. A heartfelt thank you to our amazing film and theatre department for fostering such inspiring talent!
#CIS #CISHK #FilmFestival #TheArts 
Babel Film Workshop Alison Wong

Spring is here, and your teen has places to be. Give them the freedom to request their own rides and orders with an Uber teen account, all while you stay in control with live-trip tracking and added safety features.

Sign them up now and get 50% off their first ride (up to $10 off). Terms apply.
Add a teen

Parents stay connected with:

Live trip and delivery tracking
You can follow every trip or meal order in real time from the map in your Uber app.
Highly rated drivers and couriers
Teen accounts get paired with highly-rated and experienced drivers and couriers.
Always-on safety features
Rideshare safety features like PIN verification and RideCheck are always on.
Trip notifications
Stay connected whenever they catch a ride or order their after-school snack.
Maximum savings of $10 per ride for 1 teen ride with Uber in select markets. Promo may take up to 24 hours to be applied. New Uber teen account users only. This promotion is valid only for teens who are new users and have never taken a ride with Uber. Offer not valid in California. This promotion is valid only if it has been received directly from Uber. Offer expires 7 days after signup. To activate the offer, your teen will need to apply promo code TEENSRIDES50P in the Uber app prior to requesting their first ride. Promotion does not apply to surcharges, government fee–related charges, tolls, tips, or taxes (which will be calculated based on the pre-discount amount). Offer cannot be combined with other offers or savings (except for any applicable Uber One member discount). In some cities, local regulations require a minimum charge for transportation; in such cases, a promo will not reduce the price below the required minimum charge. Offer is non-transferable. Trump Is Trying to Gain More Power Over Elections. Is His Effort Legal?

By Nick Corasaniti

Ro Khanna, who represents Silicon Valley, sees the vice president — a likely heir to President Trump’s political movement — as a unique threat to the constitutional order.

response_text:
Corny corporate games, when handled well, can help dispense with the small talk.
View in browser|nytimes.com

March 29, 2025

By Melissa Kirsch

Good morning. Icebreakers are corny, corporate get-to-know-you exercises. But there’s something thrilling in dispensing with small talk and just asking the interesting questions.

María Jesús Contreras

Breaking through

In a meeting at work last week, my colleague told the story of how she recently took her son, age 17, to his first concert, Kim Deal at the Brooklyn Paramount. She was so excited to blow his mind, to introduce him to the magic of live music that she’d discovered at 15 when she first went to a rock show herself. How cool, I thought, imagining her son, forevermore when asked “What was the first band you saw live?” getting to answer that he went with his mom to see a rock icon like Deal, bassist and frontwoman of the indisputably hip bands the Pixies and the Breeders. This occasioned everyone at the meeting revealing the first band they saw in concert.

Perhaps more than any other bit of personal trivia, I find this one fascinating. You learn about their teenage tastes in music. If their parents took them, you learn something about their childhoods. (“Oh, he had the kind of parents who took their 6-year-old to see Steely Dan!”) My colleagues’ first concerts were impressive: Duran Duran, R.E.M. on the “Monster” tour. Mine was the English rock band Squeeze, age 15, third row, Madison Square Garden.

And people love to tell you about their first concerts. It’s a jewel box of a question, an invitation to reveal something unique about themselves , to tell a well-practiced personal story. They get to convey as much or as little about your taste as you feel comfortable with — “See, I’ve always been cool” or “God, look what a dork I was.” It’s the perfect specimen of that most reviled form of corporate get-to-know-you activity: the icebreaker.

I have, over the past few days, conducted an unscientific but wholly convincing study of my friends’ feelings about icebreakers. They all, to a person, hate them. I get it. On their face, team-building exercises of any sort should be treated with suspicion. Icebreakers are meant to loosen people up. How loose, one might wonder wisely, is it ever appropriate to get at work? We’re going around the table stating our favorite breakfast cereals, innocuous enough, but I’m not sure I want to reveal anything more intimate than that to the entire marketing department.

But, as cheesy as they can be in a work context (is there anything more humiliating than trying to conjure “a fun fact about yourself”?), I will defend a good icebreaker as a delightful shortcut to a measured intimacy. In a past job where I ran a weekly staff meeting, I began each meeting with an icebreaker. A good portion of my team was remote, before remote work was normal, and it seemed impossible that we were going to get comfortable with one another without some kind of corny intervention. I may be deluding myself, but once the team members got to know one another a little, the icebreakers became a fun parlor game, a way to get closer, to remind ourselves that we were interesting, dynamic human beings even in the matrix of the workplace.

Looking back at my icebreakers from those weekly meetings, I see in my notes questions I have no idea how the people closest to me would answer, and I’m tempted to ask them. Some of these questions I devised myself, some came from the writer Rob Walkers’s newsletter “The Art of Noticing,” some came from the team. “What’s the first thing you bought with your own money?” “What were you doing at 23?” “What’s something you’re great at but hate doing?” “What are the most common things people say when you tell them your hometown?”

It might feel awkward or artificial to pose these questions in the middle of a regular conversation, but it might be fun to deliberately ask an icebreaker of your family at dinner, or a group of friends about whom you think you know everything, or your spouse. For those of us who understand the utility of small talk but deplore the slow, inefficient on-ramp of get-to-know-you questions — where are you from, what do you do, any siblings? — icebreakers do just what they claim to. You can wait for the ice to melt, or you can just smash it with a question that gets at something actually a little interesting, a little revealing. And you don’t have to call them icebreakers. Outside of a corporate framework, icebreakers are just manifestations of curiosity. What do you really want to know about the person you’re talking to? Why not just ask them?

THE LATEST NEWS

Politics

President Trump on Friday. Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
  • Federal judges blocked President Trump’s executive orders targeting two major law firms that participated in investigations of him. Another firm agreed to do $100 million in pro bono work on issues Trump supports.
  • Vice President JD Vance and a cohort of officials took a brief trip to Greenland. The reception was as chilly as the weather, David Sanger writes.
  • The Trump administration asked the Supreme Court to allow it to use a rarely invoked wartime law to deport Venezuelans with little or no due process.
  • A federal judge blocked the Trump administration from dismantling the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
  • Trump pardoned Trevor Milton, an electric truck maker convicted of fraud. And he commuted the fraud sentence of Carlos Watson, a digital media founder.
  • A federal judge temporarily halted the Trump administration’s efforts to dismantle Voice of America, the government-funded international broadcaster.

Health

  • The F.D.A.’s top vaccine official, Dr. Peter Marks, resigned and said that Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s stance on vaccines posed a danger to the public.
  • Utah became the first state to ban fluoride in public drinking water. Kennedy has called for fluoride to be removed from water nationwide.
  • Kennedy said that states could bar people from using federal food assistance to pay for soft drinks.

Other Big Stories

  • The death toll from the powerful earthquake in Myanmar has surpassed 1,000, the country’s military government said. The U.S. Geological Survey suggested that the toll could be far higher.
  • A jury convicted Charlie Javice, founder of a student aid start-up, of defrauding JPMorgan of $175 million.
  • The S&P 500 index dipped as investors weighed new and hotter-than-expected inflation data and braced for more tariffs.
  • Israel launched airstrikes near Beirut, after rockets were fired at northern Israel from Lebanese territory. Both Israel and Hezbollah said they were still committed to upholding a cease-fire that took effect last year.
  • Rescue crews are working frantically to extract a U.S. Army vehicle carrying four American soldiers that disappeared in a waterlogged forest in Lithuania.

THE WEEK IN CULTURE

Film and TV

Evan Goldberg, left, and Seth Rogen. Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
  • In “The Studio,” Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg — creative partners since childhood — poke fun at the Hollywood system that raised them.
  • “Death of a Unicorn,” about a father (Paul Rudd) and daughter (Jenna Ortega) who run down a mythical beast, is wall-to-wall goofs, our critic writes.
  • The Netflix series “Adolescence” has prompted debate in Britain about children’s smartphone use.
  • Disney’s live-action remake of “Snow White” opened to paltry box office numbers.
  • ChatGPT’s image creator has gotten good at imitating the style of Studio Ghibli, the beloved Japanese animation house. The internet is now flooded with Ghibli-fied memes.

Music

Justin Vernon of Bon Iver. Thea Traff for The New York Times
  • Justin Vernon’s early success with Bon Iver left him drained. His next album — “Sable, Fable” — is a moment of reinvention. Listen to his conversation with the hosts of Popcast.
  • Boost your mood this weekend with these new up-tempo songs, recommended by the Times’s pop music editor.

More Culture

  • President Trump is trying to change the way Smithsonian Institution depicts American history. Its museums and libraries, he says, should emphasize “American greatness.”
  • “The Great Gatsby” turns 100 this year. The Times critic A.O. Scott explores the way it’s shaped our pop culture.
  • The Museum of Modern Art in New York announced that its next director will be Christophe Cherix, a veteran curator who led its drawings and prints department.
  • L.J. Smith, the author of the “Vampire Diaries” book series that became a popular TV show, died at 66.
  • Trump wants to pare back or eliminate the Institute of Museum and Library Services, an independent agency. Library supporters are rallying to its defense.
  • Jenifer Ringer, the celebrated New York City Ballet principal, is back at the School of American Ballet in a new role: teacher and guiding light.

CULTURE CALENDAR

🎬 “A Minecraft Movie” (Friday): This movie will have references — to things like water buckets, Creepers and Ender pearls — that go over your head. But they’ll delight the kids in your moviegoing party. Hopefully the high jinks of Jack Black and Jason Momoa bumbling through a video game realm prove entertaining enough that even the newbies can enjoy their time in the Overworld.

RECIPE OF THE WEEK

Yossy Arefi for The New York Times

By Melissa Clark

Earl Grey Tea Cake

For a not-too-sweet dessert that will keep well into the week, there’s Samantha Seneviratne’s moist and tender Earl Grey tea cake with dark chocolate and orange zest. Its subtle floral-citrus scent comes from loose tea leaves stirred into the buttery cake batter, which is also liberally speckled with chopped dark chocolate. Serve thick wedges after dinner or for a midafternoon snack, preferably accompanied by a pot of Earl Grey tea.

REAL ESTATE

Donn and Alexandra Calder Jennifer Chase for The New York Times

The Hunt: A couple with a $350,000 budget searched for a home on the sea. Which boat did they choose? Play our game.

At home with: See inside the spacious Potomac, Md., home of a film producer couple.

What you get for $55,000: A 1912 Queen Anne Revival house in Harpers Ferry, W.V.; a condo in an 1840 house in Charleston, S.C.; or a shingled house in New Bedford, Mass.

Mortgages: Trump administration officials are ramping up talks of privatizing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. This is what it will mean for home buyers.

T MAGAZINE

Mikael Olsson

Click the image above to read this weekend’s edition of T, The New York Times Style Magazine.

LIVING

Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

Art of craft: Nails are the canvas for her mind-boggling creations.

Manhattan: T.J. Byrnes, a no-frills Irish pub in the Financial District, has started attracting the young and hip.

Digital art, IRL: Qualeasha Wood incorporates distorted self-portraits and internet memes into her tapestries.

Lexicon: The Oxford English Dictionary added 42 new words borrowed from other languages, including “gigil,” a Tagalog expression for witnessing something adorable.

Achy knees? This exercise can help.

ADVICE FROM WIRECUTTER

How to become a birder without going birding

If you feel called to bask in the springtime delight that is bird-watching, but don’t have the time to camp out and patiently spy, consider setting up a smart bird feeder. Our favorites look just like regular feeders, but they come equipped with cameras that capture high-quality, up-close shots of avian visitors. They’ll send you smartphone alerts when birds come by, and even record videos or photos of their escapades — perfect for sparking some joy in your group chats. Also: We’ve spotted deals on both of our top-pick feeders as part of this weekend’s spring sales. — Brittney Ho

GAME OF THE WEEK

Agnes Emma-Nnopu of TCU, left, and Hannah Hidalgo of Notre Dame. AP Photo/Tony Gutierrez, Michael Reaves/Getty Images

Notre Dame vs. TCU, women’s N.C.A.A. tournament: Notre Dame’s past three seasons have ended in the Sweet Sixteen round. Can it avoid the same fate this year? The Irish defense has been great, thanks in large part to Hannah Hidalgo, the ACC’s defensive player of the year. But TCU’s offense can be tough to stop when Hailey Van Lith gets her pick-and-roll game going with Sedona Prince. Today at 1 p.m. Eastern on ESPN

NOW TIME TO PLAY

Here is today’s Spelling Bee. Yesterday’s pangrams were headphone and openhanded.

Take the news quiz to see how well you followed this week’s headlines.

And here are today’s Mini Crossword, Wordle, Sudoku, Connections, Sports Connections and Strands.

Thanks for spending part of your weekend with The Times. — Melissa

Think on it while you scroll through the newsletter and we’ll let you know the answer at the bottom. Have an epic weekend. —Sam Klebanov, Molly Liebergall, Matty Merritt, Abby Rubenstein, Neal Freyman MARKETS Nasdaq $-- --% S&P $-- --% Dow $-- --% 10-Year --% -- bps Bitcoin $-- --% Lululemon $-- --% Data is provided by *Stock data as of market close. Here's what these numbers mean. Markets: Stocks fell yesterday like Wile E. Coyote after he made the mistake of looking down as investors grappled with the Fed’s favorite inflation gauge coming in hotter than expected, plunging consumer sentiment, and continued uncertainty over tariffs. Lululemon sank after the purveyor of pricey yoga pants became the latest retailer to warn that consumers are pulling back.   Markets Sponsored by The Crew Dive deeper. Looking for in-depth markets coverage in the Brew style you know and love? Brew Markets serves up daily analysis of the investing landscape to help you make sense of market moves. Subscribe now. LEGAL Trump pardoned the founder of Nikola Trevor Milton pardon announcement @trevormiltonofficial/Instagram This week, President Trump handed a get-out-of-jail-free card to Trevor Milton, the founder of hydrogen-electric truck company Nikola. Though he was sentenced in 2023 to four years behind bars after being found guilty of defrauding investors by exaggerating Nikola's progress in developing a hydrogen-powered 18-wheeler, Milton was free on bail pending an appeal decision. In a video announcing his “full and unconditional pardon,” Milton proclaimed that “the greatest comeback story in America is about to happen.” Comeback from what? Nikola went public via a SPAC merger in 2020, and for a time it appeared to be a clean tech powerhouse, boasting a $30 billion valuation that surpassed Ford’s at the time. The company promised to usher in a future of emissions-free trucking, but in the meantime, it was losing money on every vehicle it sold, and questions emerged about its plans. A 2020 short-seller’s report accused Nikola of making false claims about its tech, revealing that a demo video that claimed to show a working truck prototype actually featured a nonfunctioning semi rolling downhill.The claims prompted a government investigation that led to the prosecution (and conviction) of Milton. Nikola’s stock quickly rolled off a cliff as investors realized that part of its offering was vaporware, and the company filed for bankruptcy last month. And now… Milton, who donated $1.8 million to Trump’s 2024 re-election effort, called him an “amazing man,” saying that the president had compared his case to the ones brought against himself that Trump claims were politically motivated. Yesterday, Trump said he believed Milton’s misdeed was supporting “a gentleman named Donald Trump for a president.” The pardon not only keeps Milton out of prison, but also means he can’t be ordered to pay the $680 million in restitution to defrauded investors that federal prosecutors recently requested. He’s not the only comeback king. Trump previously pardoned Ross Ulbricht, the founder of the dark web marketplace Silk Road, who was serving a life sentence for operating a website that functioned as a go-to for drug dealers but was lauded by die-hard libertarians. And yesterday, he commuted the criminal fraud sentence of Ozy Media founder Carlos Watson.—SK     Presented By Studio by Tishman Speyer Come together at Rockefeller Center Studio by Tishman Speyer Take your next event from drab to fab when you host it at the iconic Rockefeller Center. Studio by Tishman Speyer’s meetings and events venue on the 27th floor of 45 Rockefeller Plaza is designed for success. With stunning views of the plaza, tons of natural light, and a reliable onsite team, this space can make you the host with the most. Impress guests and host unforgettable celebrations, conferences, and more in the heart of NYC. Studio by Tishman Speyer is designed to support you every step of the way, from planning to execution, full-service catering, tech support, and more. See this rare event space for yourself—and dazzle guests for any occasion. Book here.  WORLD Tour de headlines People stand past the debris of a collapsed building in Mandalay after an earthquake. STR/Getty Images Myanmar earthquake leaves more than 150 people dead. The 7.7 magnitude quake struck near Myanmar ’s second-largest city, Mandalay, leveling buildings. It shook the ground as far as neighboring Thailand—where it caused an under-construction high-rise to collapse, killing at least 10 people. As of yesterday, authorities said that at least 144 died in the quake in Myanmar, with over 700 more injured and the death toll expected to rise. The leader of Myanmar's military junta requested international aid to help in the aftermath. CoreWeave’s market debut was not a triumph for AI. CoreWeave’s IPO was meant to be a test of investors’ appetite for AI and for new stock listings…and it seems like they might not be so hungry for either. The company, which rents out Nvidia chips to AI companies, had already priced shares in its initial offering lower than anticipated at $40, and after seesawing throughout the day, the stock closed at about the same price. But some issues may have been about CoreWeave itself, since investors were also concerned about how concentrated its customer base is. Charlie Javice found guilty of defrauding JPMorgan. The startup founder—who once mused that Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes should get a light sentence for defrauding “sophisticated ***holes”—was convicted yesterday of lying to JPMorgan when selling Frank to the bank for $175 million in 2021. Prosecutors convinced a New York jury that Javice, a Wharton grad who was featured in Forbes magazine's “30 Under 30” list in 2019, had not been frank, convincing the bank her financial aid tool had 4.25 million customers when it really only had 300,000. The jury also found her co-defendant, Frank's former chief growth officer, guilty. Javice is expected to appeal.—AR HOMEBUYING Florida mulls scrapping property taxes in US first Florida house Joe Raedle/Getty Images Amid a soaring cost of living, leaders of one of the tax-friendliest states in the country are considering making it even tax-friendlier, but some officials say the proposed move could blow a hole in local budgets. Sunshine State lawmakers introduced dozens of bills this month aimed at lowering property taxes, including legislation that could do away with it altogether, at Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis’s urging. For context: The median property tax bill in Jacksonville and Tampa jumped nearly 60% between 2019 and 2024 as property values boomed, according to Redfin.In comparison, median US property taxes rose 23.6% from 2019 to 2023. Florida already doesn’t have a state income tax, so according to the nonprofit Florida Policy Institute… Property taxes provide 18% of county revenue, 17% of city/town revenue, and 50%-60% of school district funding.Florida sales tax would need to at least double to 12% to make up for property tax losses. But…DeSantis said he doesn’t want to raise the sales tax. Instead, he’s proposed cutting spending or taxing tourists more. It’s a big hole to fill: Republican state Sen. Don Gaetz told the Wall Street Journal he hasn’t seen “any proposal” for chopping property taxes that “ensures that local governments will still have the funds to operate efficiently.”—ML     Together With Chase Good vibes only. Whether you’re planning a new album listening party, plotting a movie marathon, gearing up for an all-day gaming sesh, or reorganizing your vinyl collection, Chase Pay Over Time® can help get your entertainment setup ready. In partnership with Chase, we created a quiz to help you put together your dream setup while staying on budget. Take the quiz. SUPPLY CHAIN Robbery on the Nike Express BNSF train Don Crawford/Melinda Crawford/Getty Images It’s going to be hard imagining a train robbery story without Brad Pitt in it, but you must try. Criminals are increasingly targeting cargo trains from Warren Buffett-owned BNSF in California and Arizona headed east along Interstate 40. Cargo thefts have spiked. There were 65,000+ thefts in 2024, 40% more than the previous year. Those thefts cost the industry $100+ million, according to the Association of American Railroads. Authorities believe that thieves identify high-value shipments either from warehouse worker tips or by looking for visible locks on containers. Then they either cut air hoses to trigger emergency stops, or wait for routine stops in less populated areas, and offload merch into vehicles nearby or stash it in brush near the tracks for pickup. Nike sneakers are thieves’ biggest target, but other recent loot includes gaming headsets and smart vacuums.In the last year, 9 out of 10 heists targeting BNSF trains in the Mojave Desert involved Nikes. Turns out it’s pretty easy to rob a train. Conductors often don’t even know they are being robbed, as containers can be as far as three miles back. Plus, it’s almost impossible to protect the more than 140,000 miles of tracks across the country used by rail companies. Read more about recent cargo thefts from our friends at CFO Brew here.—MM     STAT Prime number: AirbnBeyoncé Beyonce Knowles performing songs from Cowboy CarterBrooke Sutton/Getty Images The BeyHive is abuzz and ready to fly. Since their queen started selling tickets for her “Cowboy Carter” tour last month, Beyoncé’s fans have sent searches on Airbnb in the surrounding areas soaring, Axios reports. In Beyoncé’s native Houston, searches were up 620% for the nights she’ll be performing compared to the previous year, the company told Axios. Searches were also up 400% in Atlanta, 150% in DC, and 100% in Chicago for the dates she’ll be in those cities. Fans will also likely be staying in hotels—and patronizing local restaurants and other businesses, giving local economies a Beyoncé bump. It wouldn’t be the first time the pop diva has had a major economic impact: In 2023, economists at Danske Bank said Beyoncé’s Renaissance World Tour performances in Stockholm were responsible for an unexpected monthly rise in inflation in Sweden.—AR Together With Golf Digest+ Golf Digest+ Access to the best in golf. Masters treasures went missing, and then the FBI showed up. The first item the young man stole from Augusta National was a green-and-white golf towel, and that’s just how the story begins. Read about it on Golf Digest+. NEWS What else is brewing Elon Musk said he sold X to his similarly named company xAI in an all-stock deal that valued xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion.The FCC is investigating DEI initiatives at Disney and ABC.BlackRock’s deal to buy two Panama Canal ports has reportedly been delayed while Chinese antitrust regulators probe it.Big Law firms Jenner & Block and WilmerHale sued to challenge President Trump’s executive orders against them, while competitor Skadden promised to do $100 million in free legal work to avoid getting hit with one.JD Vance criticized Denmark’s rule of Greenland during his controversial visit there.A federal judge ordered the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to rehire staff and get back to work.Utah became the first state to ban fluoride in public drinking water. response_text:
Republicans and Democrats both think Elon Musk will help them win a key Wisconsin race.
View in browser|nytimes.com

March 28, 2025

Musk’s Washington

A close look at how Elon Musk is trying to transform the government.

Good evening. Tonight, we head to Wisconsin, where Republicans don’t seem to mind Democrats’ efforts to frame a key State Supreme Court race around Elon Musk. Plus, we’ve got a look at the DOGE playbook, and our takeaways from the group’s effort to soften its image. We’ll start with the latest.

  • Elon Musk walked back part of his legally questionable plan to pay conservative-leaning voters in Wisconsin’s Supreme Court election on Tuesday.
  • He also said on Friday that he had sold X, his social media company, to xAI, the artificial intelligence start-up he founded in 2023, in an unusual arrangement that may raise conflict-of-interest questions.
  • Republicans in Congress are skipping oversight of the Department of Government Efficiency, trying instead to head off cuts that would affect their constituents.
  • After some chefs said they wouldn’t work for Musk, Tesla found one for its retro-futuristic diner in Los Angeles, Pete Wells reports. It’s Eric Greenspan, a developer of delivery-only restaurants.
A protest outside a campaign event for Brad Schimel, the conservative candidate in the Wisconsin Supreme Court race, in Eau Claire, Wis., on Wednesday. Jim Vondruska for The New York Times

As Democrats rail against Musk, Republicans shrug

By Jess Bidgood

Outside a wedding venue in Stoughton, Wis., the other night, a group of Democratic protesters unfurled an enormous “For Sale” sign and a giant check while a man dressed as Elon Musk pursed his lips. It was meant to represent the millions that the world’s richest man had spent on behalf of Brad Schimel, the conservative candidate for State Supreme Court in Wisconsin who was about to appear inside.

“Elon has just taken over the presidency,” fumed Mary Nervig, a resident of nearby McFarland who had joined the protest. Now, she worried, Musk could take over Wisconsin’s highest court, too.

Inside the venue, though, Musk barely came up during a marathon of speeches. Not by name, at least.

“Isn’t it great,” former Gov. Tommy Thompson told his fellow Republicans from the stage, that Republicans and Democrats in the race were “spending almost on par for the first time?”

Indeed, Musk has spent some $20 million on behalf of the conservative candidate, Brad Schimel, erasing what has in recent years been a Democratic fund-raising advantage in the state. But Wisconsin Democrats are betting that a focus on Musk’s role in the race will turbocharge their base, firing up supporters like Nervig, as they try to preserve the court’s narrow liberal majority. They’ve put his face in campaign ads and even named a statewide tour “The People v. Musk.”

“As much as it is a choice between these two Supreme Court justices, it is also a way to send a message about what Musk and Trump are doing,” Ben Wikler, the Wisconsin Democratic chairman, told supporters at an event I attended in Eau Claire last week.

If any of that spooks Republicans, they’re not showing it. They’ve welcomed Musk’s money. And when I asked Brian Schimming, the Wisconsin Republican chairman, how his party should respond to the charge that Musk is trying to buy a State Supreme Court seat, his answer was simple.

“Not at all, to be honest with you,” Schimming said. “I’ve spent about one second worrying about what they say about Elon Musk.”

It made for an odd contrast when I was in Wisconsin on Tuesday: The only places I didn’t hear about Musk were the campaign events for his chosen candidate.

At first, I wondered if this reflected some discomfort with President Trump’s billionaire buddy on the part of Republicans on the ground in Wisconsin. After all, polls show that Musk is pretty unpopular.

But Musk isn’t unpopular with the crowds turning out to see Schimel. One retiree, Renee Hynes, went to see Schimel at a sports bar in Jefferson, Wis., wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with both Musk’s and Trump’s faces.

“I love Elon Musk,” she said, before pointing out that Democrats take money from plenty of big donors, too.

Charlie Untz, a 76-year-old dairy farmer in a barn jacket, said Musk was doing a “great thing” for the country. “I wish he’d dig even deeper,” he said.

“I think he loves America,” said Karen Gartzke, 80.

These voters seemed to embody something Schimming, the Republican chair, had told me about Musk. “Because he’s associated with Trump, they’re fine,” he said, referring to Republican voters.

Just like Democrats, Republicans are hoping that Musk will actually fire up their voters. His planned trip to Wisconsin this weekend is further evidence of that bet.

And if Republicans are right, Democrats’ reminders about Schimel’s support from Musk could actually end up helping, rather than hurting, him.

AGENCY REPORT

The DOGE playbook

Several of my colleagues have laid out the blueprint that has emerged for the Department of Government Efficiency’s method of operations.

The department places staff members in key offices. They gain access to data and systems. Then agency contracts, spending and jobs are cut.

At the Department of Agriculture, civil servants were told to follow a flow chart like this one to identify contracts to eliminate, according to an internal agency document.

By The New York Times

See more of the DOGE playbook here.

More on government agencies

  • A federal judge on Friday temporarily halted Trump’s efforts to dismantle Voice of America. The broadcaster’s journalists had argued in a lawsuit that the administration’s actions violated their First Amendment rights.
  • Trump’s budget chief, Russell Vought, is aiming to marry extreme austerity with Christian values, my colleague Tony Romm writes.
Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, at President Trump’s inauguration in January. Kenny Holston/The New York Times

MEANWHILE ON X

Musk throws a little shade at Mark Zuckerberg

My colleague Kate Conger, who is tracking Musk’s activity on X, parses a one-word post that appeared to cast critical attention on another platform: Facebook.

Elon Musk has a lot to say online. But even when he is at his most laconic, more is often going on than meets the eye.

That was the case on Friday, when Musk wrote “Hmm” in response to a complaint on X by one of his followers that a fact check had been added to his Facebook post about long Covid. The fact check noted that long Covid was not considered a “vaccine injury.”

Musk has previously shared his own skepticism about Covid vaccines, posting on X in 2023 that he experienced “major side effects” after a booster shot and adding, “Hopefully, no permanent damage, but I dunno.”

Musk’s interest in the post, however, may well have had more to do with Facebook’s continued reliance on fact-checking.

Back in 2021, before Musk bought Twitter (and renamed it X), the company was experimenting with letting users add corrections to misleading posts. The crowdsourcing program, known as Birdwatch, was meant to copy Wikipedia’s open-editing model and improve accuracy.

In 2022, when Musk took over the platform, he liked the crowdsourcing idea so much that he expanded it sharply. Musk viewed content moderation as akin to censorship and preferred to put such decisions in the hands of users. So he effectively replaced all of Twitter’s content-moderation work with Birdwatch, which — in a purge of all avian-themed nomenclature — he renamed Community Notes.

Independent researchers who study Community Notes have found that the program is effective for combating misinformation when there is widespread agreement about the truth. But they say it is less useful for correcting misleading posts about political content, because users often can’t agree on the truth about a polarizing issue.

Still, Facebook announced this year — just as Trump was set to begin his second term — that it would follow X’s example and replace fact-checking with Community Notes. The move was seen as a concession to the incoming administration, and was celebrated by Musk as a sign of X’s policy prowess.

That work, however, has barely begun at Meta, the company that owns Facebook. Meta just started testing its version of Community Notes last week, with 200,000 contributors across Facebook, Instagram and Threads.

Musk's one-word post suggests he may be growing impatient.

— Kate Conger

Steve Davis, a longtime Musk ally who now essentially leads DOGE, in 2018. Patrick Fallon/ZUMA Wire, via Alamy Live News

ON THE AIR

The charm offensive

I’ve been interested in how, after revealing little publicly about who works for DOGE or what those people do, Musk and his team of cost-cutters have begun something of a charm offensive by participating in friendly interviews on Fox News. I asked my colleague Theodore Schleifer, who covers Musk and other billionaires, to tell us what he took away from a segment of one such interview that aired last night.

So much of the news media’s coverage of DOGE has centered on either Musk or “the kids,” as they’ve become known — the 20-somethings who have been his foot soldiers at various departments in Washington. This interview, in which seven members of the department joined Musk to answer softball questions from Bret Baier, showed how Musk is trying to shift the coverage.

  • It largely did not feature “the kids.” Many of the people who work for DOGE are middle-career entrepreneurs from Silicon Valley or Washington veterans. The Fox News interview highlighted people like Anthony Armstrong, a former Morgan Stanley banker, and Brad Smith, an experienced D.C. player. The effect, and most likely the intent, was to project a more serious image of the DOGE operation than is often portrayed.
  • Steve Davis stepped into the spotlight. This longtime Musk ally, who essentially leads DOGE, has what his friends describe as a healthy paranoia of being in the public eye. So I was struck to see Davis, seated on Musk’s left, participate in this interview, even if he did resist Baier’s description of him as DOGE’s chief operating officer.
  • Musk is embracing conventional public relations. He believes he is his own best publicist and generally disparages the traditional news media. The extensive interview suggests he is learning the limits of that approach. “Should have done it sooner,” Musk posted afterward on X.

— Theodore Schleifer

Got a Tip?

The Times offers several ways to send important information confidentially.

MORE POLITICS NEWS AND ANALYSIS

Jason Andrew for The New York Times

On Trump, Democrats and a New Era of Politics: A Look at the Year Ahead

Special elections are already pointing to a familiar pattern.

By Nate Cohn

Donald J. Trump X account, via Associated Press; Kenny Holston/The New York Times; Justice Department, via Associated Press

A Disregard for the Rules Trickles Down From Trump to His Aides

Many of the people serving in the administration do not have decades of experience in government, or deep knowledge of its rules and why they exist, former officials say.

By Julian E. Barnes

Scott Strazzante/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press

The Progressive Congressman Who Wants to Take On JD Vance

Ro Khanna, who represents Silicon Valley, sees the vice president — a likely heir to President Trump’s political movement — as a unique threat to the constitutional order.

By Shane Goldmacher

Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times

Trump Mentioned Biden 316 Times in 50 Days, Mostly to Blame Him for Things

A central dictum in the Trump White House is that Joseph R. Biden Jr. is to blame for just about anything and everything.

By Shawn McCreesh and Dylan Freedman

Pool photo by Jim Watson

JD Vance and a U.S. Delegation Arrive in a Wary Greenland

After initial plans for a visit from American officials were met with a backlash, Friday’s trip has been limited to a stop at a remote military base.

By Tim Balk

To view this email online, paste this link into your browser:
https://t.e2ma.net/message/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n




Kelly Writers House

3805 Locust Walk

Philadelphia, PA 19104

215-746-POEM

wh@writing.upenn.edu (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/g0h04ec)

Become a Friend

Friends of the Kelly Writers House give gifts that support

specific projects or general programming, semester by semester. 

Give online: writing.upenn.edu/wh/support/online.php (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/wsi04ec)

THIS WEEK AT THE KELLY WRITERS HOUSE

* Call 215-746-POEM (215-746-7636) for updates *

EVENT IS FULL 

A READING BY CARMEN MARIA MACHADO

Monday, March 31st, 6:30 PM (ET) in person

Kelly Writers House Fellows Program (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/clj04ec)

Hosted by Al Filreis

Calendar link (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/sdk04ec)

Carmen Maria Machado is the author of the bestselling memoir In the Dream House, the graphic novel The Low, Low Woods, and the award-winning short story collection Her Body and Other Parties. She is the former Abrams Artist-in-Residence at the University of Pennsylvania. Her Body and Other Parties was listed as a member of “The New Vanguard” by the New York Times in 2018, as one of “15 remarkable books by women that are shaping the way we read and write fiction in the 21st century.” Her essays, fiction, poetry, and criticism have appeared in the New Yorker, the New York Times, Granta, Vogue, This American Life, Harper’s Bazaar, Tin House, McSweeney's Quarterly Concern, The Believer, Guernica, Best American Science Fiction & Fantasy, Best American Nonrequired Reading, and elsewhere. She holds an MFA from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop. She is a 2019 recipient of a Guggenheim fellowship, and a visiting associate professor at the Iowa Writers' Workshop in Spring 2021.

A CONVERSATION WITH CARMEN MARIA MACHADO
Tuesday, April 1st, 10:00 AM (ET) in person

Kelly Writers House Fellows Program (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/85k04ec)

Hosted by Al Filreis

Calendar link (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/oyl04ec)

RSVP required; seating strictly limited: whfellow@writing.upenn.edu (mailto:http://whfellow@writing.upenn.edu)

Carmen Maria Machado is the author of the bestselling memoir In the Dream House, the graphic novel The Low, Low Woods, and the award-winning short story collection Her Body and Other Parties. She is the former Abrams Artist-in-Residence at the University of Pennsylvania. Her Body and Other Parties was listed as a member of “The New Vanguard” by the New York Times in 2018, as one of “15 remarkable books by women that are shaping the way we read and write fiction in the 21st century.” Her essays, fiction, poetry, and criticism have appeared in the New Yorker, the New York Times, Granta, Vogue, This American Life, Harper’s Bazaar, Tin House, McSweeney's Quarterly Concern, The Believer, Guernica, Best American Science Fiction & Fantasy, Best American Nonrequired Reading, and elsewhere. She holds an MFA from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop. She is a 2019 recipient of a Guggenheim fellowship, and a visiting associate professor at the Iowa Writers' Workshop in Spring 2021.

SPEAKEASY OPEN MIC NIGHT 

Poetry, prose, anything goes

Wednesday, April 2nd, 7:00 PM (ET) in person

Calendar link (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/4qm04ec)

Register here to attend in person (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/kjn04ec)

Our student-run open mic night welcomes all kinds of readings, performances, spectacles, and happenings. You'll have three minutes at the podium to perform. Bring your poetry, your guitar, your dance troupe, you award-winning essay, or your flash fiction to share.

DANCING ON THE SHORE: POEMS FROM MIGRATION LETTERS

A reading by M. Nzadi Keita

Thursday, April 3rd, 5:30 PM (ET) in person

Brave Testimony: A Celebration of Poetry of the African Diaspora

Sponsored by The Center for Africana Studies (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/0bo04ec)

Calendar link (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/g4o04ec)

Register here to attend in person (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/wwp04ec)

Join us for a reading by acclaimed poet M. Nzadi Keita. Keita is the author of three books of poetry, most recently Migration Letters: Poems, a poetry collection that reflects on intimate aspects of Black history, culture, and identity, revealing an uncommon gaze on working-class Philadelphia from the 1960s to the present day. This reading is part of Brave Testimony: A Celebration of Poetry of the African Diaspora and is sponsored by the Center for Africana Studies at Penn and co-sponsored by the Kelly Writers House. 

M. Nzadi Keita's third book, Migration Letters: Poems, reflects on her upbringing and coming of age as a Black working-class woman in Philadelphia (originally Lenapehoking). Keita straddles the personal and public, testifying to unsung aspects of Black culture and paying tribute to Black artists throughout: poets like Sonia Sanchez, Etheridge Knight, Amiri Baraka, and Al Young, and musicians including Chaka Khan and jazz saxophonist Pharaoh Sanders. In her second book, Brief Evidence of Heaven: Poems from the Life of Anna Murray Douglass, Keita used persona to unveil Frederick Douglass’s first wife. She is a Cave Canem alumna, a Pew Fellow, and a Leeway Foundation grantee.

The Brave Testimony series celebrates the poetry of the African diaspora. Brave Testimony readers have included Patricia Smith, Airea D. Matthews, Chris Abani, Herman Beavers, Nikky Finney, Terrance Hayes, Brenda Marie Osbey, and others.

DIGITAL PROJECTS

Sign up for ModPo

Want to join a community of 50,000+ people discussing poetry? Enroll in ModPo (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/cpq04ec) on Coursera, led by KWH Director Al Filreis and the ModPo team.

Watch events online
Watch select livestreams at the KWH YouTube channel (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/shr04ec).

Listen to poetry recordings
Listen to poetry recordings at PennSound (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/89r04ec), an ongoing project committed to producing new audio recordings and preserving existing audio archives, or PoemTalk (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/o2s04ec), a rountable dicussion of poetry in the PennSound archove. 

WRITING AND READING GROUPS

The Writers House is proud to host a number of ongoing writing and reading groups. For more information about joining the following groups, contact the group organizers listed below.

CURIOUSER
A speculative fiction creative writing group. We aim to explore the fantastic, science-fictional, eery, otherworldly, or in any other way imaginary. For more information, contact Héctor Cruz at ingmaralbizu@gmail.com (mailto:ingmaralbizu@gmail.com).

DOUBLESPEAK
A journal on and of translation. We strive to represent and celebrate a number of different languages, countries, and cultures by publishing interpretations of the work of poets and writers across centuries and around the world. For more information, email staff@doublespeakmagazine.org (mailto:staff@doublespeakmagazine.org).

THE FIBER ARTS CIRCLE

The Kelly Writers House Fiber Arts Circle is an intentional space for students and community members to share, learn, and feel supported in their fiber arts practices (no experience necessary!). Knitters, crocheters, weavers, macrame artists, needlepointers, cross-stitchers, etc. — all are welcome. For more information, contact Zuza Jevremovic at  zuza@sas.upenn.edu (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/4ut04ec).

F-WORD
A journal of feminism, gender, and sexuality. You can learn more at upennfword.com (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/knu04ec) or email upennfword@gmail.com (mailto:upennfword@gmail.com).

PENN APPETIT
A journal of food and food writing. For more information, email pennappetit@gmail.com (mailto:pennappetit@gmail.com).

PENN AND PENCIL CLUB
A creative writing workshop for Penn employees. For more information, contact Luellen Fletcher at luellen@upenn.edu (mailto:luellen@upenn.edu).

PENN MOVIEGOER
A student-run publication dedicated to film criticism and appreciation. For more information, contact Phoebe Weintraub at phowein@sas.upenn.edu (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/0fv04ec).

PENN REVIEW
The premier mainstream magazine devoted to the literary and visual arts on Penn's campus. The magazine accepts literary and visual arts submissions for annual publication. For more information, email pennreview@gmail.com (mailto:pennreview@gmail.com).

QUAKE

Quake is a magazine about sex and sexuality. The magazine uses literature, photography, design, and other art forms to facilitate the appreciation of bodies, relationships, sex, and love of all kinds. For more information, email quakemagpenn@gmail.com (https://t.e2ma.net/click/kjn8uk/gwqg0a4n/g8v04ec).

SUPPOSE AN EYES
A poetry workshop where poets can come to share and discuss their work. For more information contact Pat Green at patricia78@aol.com (mailto:patricia78@aol.com).

The move is the first for a U.S. state and could have consequences for oral health, experts said.
View in browser

March 28, 2025, 9:46 a.m. ET

BREAKING NEWS

Jim Cole/Associated Press

Utah Becomes First State to Ban Fluoride in Public Water

The law comes amid renewed scrutiny of adding the mineral to drinking water, including from Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Medical experts warn the move could have consequences for oral health, especially among children.

response_text:
Plus, tariffs, an interview with the pope’s doctor and new details about F. Scott Fitzgerald’s life
View in browser|nytimes.com

March 28, 2025

Good morning. Today you’ll hear from Miriam Jordan, an immigration correspondent who has picked up on a surprising trend. We’re also covering tariffs, an interview with the pope’s doctor and new details about F. Scott Fitzgerald’s life.

Jesús, 25, arrived last year from Venezuela. Jimena Peck for The New York Times

The self-deporters

By Miriam Jordan

I cover immigration.

It is incredibly hard to deport 14 million people — the estimated number of immigrants in the United States unlawfully. First, the government has to find them. For many, it has to pry them from their lives, their jobs, their communities. That’s why the Trump administration has deported only a few thousand migrants so far, focusing mostly on those it says are criminals.

To make a real change, as Trump has promised to do, millions of people would need to leave voluntarily. So the administration is urging them — in some cases, trying to scare them enough — to “self-deport.” The Homeland Security secretary tells them in TV ads to “leave now” or be hunted down. Those who comply “may have an opportunity to return and enjoy our freedom and live the American dream.” (This is unlikely, because anyone who has been in the country illegally for a year is ineligible to return for a decade.)

Self-deportation, a longtime fantasy for immigration hawks, was popularized by Mitt Romney in a 2012 presidential debate and often mocked. But for the first time in my 15 years of reporting on this topic, immigrants tell me they’re considering it. Some have already followed through. If the climate here becomes intolerable — if the risks of being caught and severed from their families seem too high — it’s possible many more migrants will abandon the United States. Today’s newsletter is about what I’ve heard in my reporting.

Who wants to go

Migrants in Denver, Colo., in 2023. Hyoung Chang/The Denver Post, via Getty Images

In recent years, Denver has absorbed 40,000 migrants — the most per capita of any city. Most of the newcomers are Venezuelans who fled their broken country. But the city is also home to many Latino immigrants who came long ago. I visited last week to take their temperature.

Most are not inclined to bolt. Two-thirds of undocumented immigrants have been in the country for a decade or longer. Most pay taxes. They’re people like Mirna, a Mexican who crossed the border 28 years ago. Her husband owns a house-painting business. They bought a mobile home and have three American children, including a daughter serving in the Navy. Mirna, who speaks English fluently, told me she wouldn’t go back to Mexico because it would mean leaving her kids.

But recent border crossers are much more likely to consider departing. I interviewed several young men from Venezuela who are among them. They see footage of shackled migrants shuffled onto deportation planes. They watch the videos of more than 200 Venezuelan men, accused by the Trump administration of gang affiliation, being flown to a mega-prison in El Salvador. Reporting suggests that some of them may not have been gang members.

Rather than risk subjecting themselves to that ordeal, they want to leave on their own terms.

Since arriving in Denver in 2023, Cristian, 29, has delivered meals and worked on construction sites. (Like other migrants I interviewed, he worried that immigration agents would find him and spoke on the condition that I identify him only by his given name.) He sends money to his wife and children in Venezuela. Cristian does not have any tattoos, a customary gang indicator, he said. He possesses a work permit and an active asylum application, which theoretically protects him from imminent deportation.

But the enforcement climate since Trump took office has changed Cristian’s calculus “360 degrees,” he told me. With the help of an American friend who escorted him to several immigration offices, he made an appointment to appear before a judge today so he could request a voluntary departure from the United States. (Immigrants who receive formal permission to leave have an easier time returning later.)

Other Venezuelans contemplating an exit were released into the United States by border officials with orders to report to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement every few months. Recently, officials have detained and deported people when they’ve shown up for their check-ins.

ICE agents and the local authorities detain a person in Denver. Chet Strange for The New York Times

Jesús, 25, has his next ICE appointment in early May and sees the writing on the wall. After arriving last year, he languished for months in detention until officials turned him loose, probably to make room for others. He found work remodeling homes in Denver. Now he’d rather return voluntarily to Venezuela than be confined again. “I came here to work to help my family,” said Jesús, the sole brother to five sisters. “I just hope to manage to leave before they deport me.”

He has enough money to buy an airline ticket. But, like others, he told me that the U.S. authorities had confiscated his passport. How can he board a plane without it?

American women in Denver formed groups in late 2023 to help recent arrivals from Venezuela. But more recently they also share tips about how to leave because the bureaucracy can be hard to navigate. A mother with a U.S.-born child needs to get a passport for her child, for instance. But his father, who needs to sign forms, has been deported. The local volunteers have researched what happens if migrants leave without an ID — and whether it’s safer to depart by air or over land.

The departures are not exclusive to Denver. A family in Chicago recently left for Mexico, according to their lawyer. People have abandoned Springfield, Ohio — the town where Trump claimed Haitians were eating their pets — employers there told me. Others are contemplating leaving from elsewhere, like Houston.

The right moment

For now, most migrants are staying put. They’ve trekked through jungles and cartel territory to get here. Instead of giving up, they limit their outings and keep a low profile.

What could change their minds? The job market, several told me. A crackdown on U.S. businesses that employed undocumented workers would drive many into the shadows and others back home. A recession would have the same effect. Wayne Cornelius, an immigration scholar at the University of California, San Diego, has found that bleak job prospects are most likely to impel undocumented immigrants to leave.

Take Karla and Ender, a Venezuelan couple with four children. They worry about immigration enforcement. But they have plenty of work, and their family is thriving in Colorado. Since arriving in late 2023, they have relocated from a rundown apartment complex, acquired two cars and bought their kids cellphones.

“You can barely make enough money to feed your family in Venezuela,” Karla said. “We live much better here.”

Ender added, “We’ll leave once we have accomplished our goals, maybe in two years.”

More on immigration

  • Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the U.S. had revoked the visa of a Tufts University graduate student because of her support of Palestinians.
  • Rubio said the State Department is revoking visas daily, and he estimated that more than 300 people’s visa might have been revoked already.
  • Teams of masked agents in masks have approached foreign students, zip-tied them and bundled them into unmarked vehicles. These tactics are usually reserved for criminal suspects.

THE LATEST NEWS

Trump Administration

  • A federal judge ordered several Trump administration officials to preserve the messages from the Signal group chat planning attacks in Yemen.
  • Attorney General Pam Bondi suggested there probably would not be a criminal investigation into the Yemen chat.
  • The Health and Human Services Department plans to lay off 10,000 employees. The cuts will be especially deep at the F.D.A. and the C.D.C.
  • Trump asked Elise Stefanik to stay in Congress rather than serve as U.N. ambassador, amid concern about the slim voting margin that Republicans hold in the House.
  • The Trump administration challenged a California law that says schools can’t be required to tell parents when students ask to use different pronouns.

Auto Tariffs

An all-electric Porsche in Leipzig, Germany. Jens Schlueter/Getty Images
  • Shares in automakers around the world, including many in Germany, Japan and Korea, fell after Trump announced tariffs on imported cars and car parts.
  • Shares in Tesla — which makes all the cars that it sells domestically in the U.S. — rose almost 3 percent.
  • Trump’s tariffs are likely to encourage more domestic car production in the long run, economists say. But in the short term, they will probably hurt the economy.
  • Experts say the tariffs will raise the average price of a car by thousands of dollars.

Higher Education

  • The University of Michigan will eliminate its central D.E.I. program, one of the largest at a major public school. (The Times published an investigation into the program last year.)
  • When protests roiled Columbia, the school closed its campus to the public. New Yorkers say they lost a treasured public space.

International

Dr. Sergio Alfieri Guglielmo Mangiapane/Reuters
  • In an interview, the leader of Pope Francis’s medical team said the pope came close to death in the hospital and said it was a “miracle.”
  • A strong earthquake struck central Myanmar, killing at least 13 people. Follow our latest updates here.
  • The BBC said Turkey had deported a correspondent who was covering the antigovernment protests in Istanbul. Read what the protests mean for Turkey.
  • South Sudan’s defense minister put the country’s vice president under house arrest, his party said. The U.N. has warned that the detention is pushing the country back into civil war.
  • King Charles was briefly hospitalized from the side effects of his cancer treatment.

Other Big Stories

  • Archaeologists have unearthed the tomb of an unknown pharaoh in Egypt. Researchers say it probably belonged to a line of kings that, until recently, had been lost to history.
  • Companies that once helped fund Pride Month celebrations are cutting their support. Organizers blame Trump’s crusade against D.E.I.
  • The amount of sea ice on the planet reached the lowest level ever recorded in March.

Opinions

Hillary Clinton writes that the most distressing part of the Trump administration’s group chat blunder isn’t the hypocrisy; it’s the stupidity.

No one in Turkey is safe from President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s erosion of democracy. To save the country, citizens should refuse to be silent, Ekrem Imamoglu, the imprisoned mayor of Istanbul, writes.

To differentiate the plural “they” from the gender-neutral pronoun “they,” let’s capitalize the latter, John McWhorter writes.

Here are columns by David Brooks on passions and Lydia Polgreen on migration in Sweden.

Share, connect, inspire.

An article can create a heartfelt (or humorous) conversation. Share one with a friend, post one to your story or drop one in the group chat. Learn more.

MORNING READS

Budapest Akos Stiller for The New York Times

Travel: Spend 36 hours in Budapest.

A visit from God: People in Japan have chronicled what they considered a sign from God on a lake for nearly 600 years. It has disappeared.

Fashion weeks: See good hair from outside the shows.

Fly safer: Airlines allow you to carry a toddler in your lap. Experts say that’s not a good idea.

Most clicked yesterday: How to stay mentally sharp in retirement.

Lives Lived: Herb Greene was in the right place at the right time to document a seismic change in music: San Francisco in the 1960s. His portraits of the Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin and others provided a visual record of the city’s thriving rock scene. He has died at 82.

SPORTS

Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: Texas Tech narrowly beat Arkansas in overtime of a thrilling game. Duke, Florida and Alabama also advanced to the Elite Eight.

M.L.B. Opening Day: Orioles outfielder Tyler O’Neill hit a home run on Opening Day for the sixth straight year.

N.B.A.: Commissioner Adam Silver pitched the league’s 30 owners an idea for an N.B.A.-owned league in Europe, which could start as early as next year.

ARTS AND IDEAS

F. Scott Fitzgerald and his wife Zelda in 1921. Minnesota Historical Society/Corbis, via Getty Images

One ill-fated night in December 1924, F. Scott Fitzgerald got into a drunken brawl in Rome that ended in a police station. He described it as “the rottenest thing that ever happened in my life,” an event so traumatic that his biographers say he could not bear to discuss it.

He did write about it, though, fictionalizing the event twice, including in his 1934 novel “Tender is the Night.” Scholars took these accounts of the scuffle as an accurate record. But newly uncovered documents suggest Fitzgerald may have behaved even worse than his stories depicted.

More on culture

  • The Sundance Film Festival is moving to Boulder, Colo. The event has outgrown Park City, Utah, its home for the past 40 years.
  • The Atlantic picked the best poetry of the century so far.
  • The University of Maryland will welcome Kermit the Frog as its commencement speaker in May.
  • Is Melania Trump’s 2005 Dior couture wedding gown really available for resale? Or is this a hoax?
  • Late night hosts are still joking about the Signal group chat.

THE MORNING RECOMMENDS …

Linda Xiao for The New York Times

Make this viral, crunchy Dubai Chocolate bar at home.

Lower your grocery bill.

Take our news quiz.

GAMES

Here is today’s Spelling Bee. Yesterday’s pangrams were coupled, decouple and decoupled.

And here are today’s Mini Crossword, Wordle, Sudoku, Connections and Strands.

Thanks for spending part of your morning with The Times. See you tomorrow.

Correction: Yesterday’s newsletter misstated the timing of the government group chat about strikes on Yemen. It happened earlier this month, not this week.

Illustration by Matt Chase; Photographs by Shutterstock

The worst habits for your back, according to spine surgeons

By Jancee Dunn

As I write this, I’m wearing a large heating pad on my back like a cape. Why? Because when I parked my car at the grocery store, I made the mistake of twisting around to grab shopping bags from the back seat.

I felt a zing of pain in the middle of my back. Uh oh!

Research shows that over a third of U.S. adults have experienced back pain during a three-month period — but few treatments actually work, according to a new study that analyzed hundreds of trials.

So I thought it might be helpful to focus on how to prevent back pain in the first place. I’ve asked orthopedic doctors for their best tips.

Skip the “B.L.T.”

My car incident “is what we euphemistically call the B.L.T.,” or the bend, lift and twist, said Dr. Arthur L. Jenkins III, a neurosurgeon in New York City who specializes in spinal surgery.

Doing all three actions at once, whether by shoveling snow or extracting a child from a car seat, “maximizes the stress on the disc, making it more likely to rupture,” Dr. Jenkins said. “As a spine surgeon, I would never do it.”

If you are about to B.L.T., take a beat and try to do each motion separately, Dr. Jenkins said.

When lifting an object, make sure both feet are planted and your weight is evenly distributed, said Dr. Gbolabo Sokunbi, a spine surgeon at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan. Then lift from your legs instead of your arms and back, he said. Keep heavier items close to your body when picking them up, which puts less strain on your spine, Dr. Sokunbi added.

Avoid twisting altogether by having your feet face whatever you’re lifting, Dr. Jenkins added.

And be especially careful in any situation that involves heavy objects, Dr. Sokunbi advised. “I’m in my mid 40s, and I no longer help family members move furniture,” he said.

Don’t play pickleball without warming up first.

Dr. Alpesh Patel, a spine surgeon at Northwestern Medicine, often sees patients “running into trouble” with activities such as pickleball, paddle tennis and golf.

“Many people think of these as low-risk sports,” Dr. Patel said. But these activities, he said, can be jarring on the spine and often involve abrupt twisting.

For the spine, “flexibility is key,” Dr. Patel said. So build in a warm-up and stretching routine before and during these sports, recommended Dr. Patel. “For example, with golf, add a low back and chest stretch every three holes.”

Don’t overload your carry-on bag.

Several experts said they often saw patients who injured themselves lifting heavy carry-on bags into the overhead compartment of planes.

“That’s not a motion most people do every day,” Dr. Sokunbi said. So be mindful not to overload your luggage, he advised.

Before you leave for the airport, test your carry-on bag’s weight, said Dr. Rahul Shah, an orthopedic spine surgeon in New Jersey.

Lift the bag to your waist and assess whether it can be done without difficulty, he said. If not, he said, remove some items. Then see if you can lift the bag from waist level to overhead level.

“This should be a distinct, two-step process,” Dr. Shah said, because the muscles that lift the bag from floor to waist are significantly stronger than those that take it from waist to overhead. Use the same two-step process on the plane, he added. And if you’re traveling with a strong companion, he said, ask them to help you.

It’s always safer to check all of your bags, especially if you already have back issues, said Dr. Jacob Joseph, a neurosurgeon at University of Michigan Health specializing in spinal injuries.

“I personally never take a carry-on bag on planes anymore,” he said.

Steer clear of situps.

The Marine Corps phased out crunches from its physical fitness test because the exercises come with “an increased risk of injury, including lower back pain.” Instead, they subbed in planks.

While situps and crunches can strengthen your core, Dr. Joseph said, they may put a lot of stress on the discs in your spine. Core-strengthening exercises such as planks, Pilates, swimming, yoga and the elliptical machine “are a lot healthier for your back in general,” he said.

Good habits can protect your back, too, said Dr. Patricia Zheng, an associate professor in the orthopedic surgery department at University of California San Francisco.

If you sit a lot during the day, get up and move every hour to take pressure off your spine, Dr. Zheng said. Set a timer if you have to, she added.

I’d love to plug in my cape at the office, but I don’t want to alarm my co-workers. So I’ll leave it at home and try to dial down my back pain with plenty of walking.

And I’m done with the B.L.T. — unless it’s lunchtime.

West Virginia is the first U.S. state to ban virtually all artificial food dyes.

In the most sweeping move of its kind, West Virginia has banned foods containing most artificial food dyes and two preservatives. At least 20 other states are considering bills that restrict the use of certain food dyes and additives.

Can you stave off memory loss with activities such as puzzles?

It’s a common belief that doing activities such as crossword puzzles, word games or reading can help prevent age-related cognitive decline. The truth is more complicated, experts say.

Hi there,

Shahid from Elicit here.

Today I’m excited to announce a case study ( https://blog.elicit.com/case-study-oxford-pharmagenesis/ ) showing how a medical communications consultancy, Oxford PharmaGenesis, uses Elicit to help pharmaceutical clients invent and commercialize new drugs. Hopefully this gives you a concrete and inspiring example of how Elicit can help your research.

Before Elicit, Oxford PharmaGenesis' research ambitions were limited by expert researcher capacity to screen and extract from relevant papers. To meet clients budgets, they often had to help clients refine their research questions and reduce scope.

Now, Oxford PharmaGenesis uses Elicit to conduct more ambitious research. Earlier this year, a major pharma company asked for all epidemiological data, biomarkers, and prevention therapies related to transient ischaemic stroke, a common neurological condition. With Elicit, Oxford PharmaGenesis was able to conduct a "rapid literature review" of 40 research questions across almost 500 papers. "In the past, we would never have been able to conduct a rapid literature review of that scale. This technology allows us to offer clients deeper insights across larger evidence bases than ever before." said Kim Wager, Scientific Director of the AI and Data Science Team.

An example of screening in Elicit.

Tomas Rees, Director of Innovation, said, “The results are reliable, and I can easily trace any data point to a primary source to be able to confirm things if we need to. That’s important when our reputation is on the line.”

To learn more about how Oxford PharmaGenesis uses Elicit to improve their research, read the full case study ( https://blog.elicit.com/case-study-oxford-pharmagenesis/ ) here!

Thanks,

Shahid

7:40 AM: More tournament logistics

*LOGISTICS!*
*Cars*
Cars for this tournament can be found here
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1lcbSS2JhndMbkOQzH8Uq2jZXCUMztIRnA2jvM3sCSNc/edit?usp=sharing>
, *please let me (Phillip) know as soon as possible if there's any changes
to be made.*

*Where*
The address of our Airbnb is 104 Drexel Ct, Rehoboth Beach, DE 19971
<https://maps.app.goo.gl/pZB24L9GMBomTu4WA>. You'll notice it's pretty
close to the beach and boardwalk. I can't guarantee anything, but I'm
hoping we'll have an opportunity to go.

*Tournament*
Our games on Saturday will be played at the* DE Turf Sports Complex,
Frederica, DE, *which can be found here
<https://maps.app.goo.gl/nufgKUNMAE4JKuiw5>. Our first game is bright and
early at *8:00 am*. We're getting to the fields at *6:45 AM!!!!* This will
be a four-game tourney day, so get ready to play a ton of frisbee and make
sure you *GET YOUR SLEEP IN*. Sunday games will likely wrap up around 3 so
be prepared to get back to campus at 5-6 ish depending on how much cars
stop. There's a chance our games end at like 4:30 instead so in that case
we'd be back later. Let me know if you if there's any issues with this,
since we could have a solution.

*Things to Bring*
*- Clothes *The weather looks pretty nice actually, maybe even as high as
70s on Saturday. I'd bring stuff comfortable to play in at that temp and
also more clothes for warming up when the day starts colder. Also bringing
beach stuff could be a move idk (still idk what's going on so don't get mad
at me if beach doesn't happen)
*- Equipment *Water bottle, light, dark, cleats, SUNSCREEN skin cancer is
serious
*- Sleeping Stuff *We should have room in most cars so please bring
anything and everything you have for you and others to sleep. If you
suspect you'll need extra room, lmk and we can find a car for that.
*- Toiletries *Bring everything you need for showering and brushing ur
teeth and hygiene stuff
*- *Snacks, caffeine, painkillers as needed, energy

As always, if you have any questions, please reach out.

Sincerely,
Void

response_text:
Plus, are you smarter than A.I.?
View in browser|nytimes.com

March 27, 2025

Good morning! Please welcome to the stage your commencement speaker: Kermit the Frog. As well-known figures head to college campuses across the country to impart wisdom to graduates, those at the University of Maryland will hear from perhaps the most accomplished figure of all: the world’s most famous green frog. — Hannah Wulkan

Are you smarter than A.I.?

The New York Times

Every day, new A.I. developments seem to move us closer to one day bowing down to our robot overlords. But while some experts predict that artificial intelligence will surpass human intelligence within the next few years, it’s not there yet. Play this puzzle to see how far the machines have to go.

Here’s what you need to know

  • Trump administration: Elon Musk’s cost-cutting effort targeted FEMA, claiming it had provided funding to house undocumented immigrants. Now disaster-stricken communities are paying the price. And the federal government detained a graduate student at Tufts even though she had a valid visa.
  • Tariffs: President Trump said he would impose a 25 percent tariff on cars and car parts, a move that is likely to raise prices. And he threatened Europe and Canada if they banded together to “do economic harm” to America.
  • Russia-Ukraine war: European leaders are trying to hammer out plans to support Ukraine. Meanwhile, Ukrainian soldiers on the front line are a world away from peace talks, as they are hunted by drones, stalked by snipers and surrounded by minefields.
  • Pride pullback: Many companies are dropping their support of Pride events this year amid Trump’s widening crusade against diversity, equity and inclusion.
  • “Pedophile hunters”: A vigilante phenomenon has been playing out online for almost a decade, with content creators posing as minors on dating apps and websites and then targeting the people who message them. These efforts have become more violent — and more viral.

On a lighter note …

Two things you didn’t really need to know but now do:

  • Going once, going twice, it’s … Melania Trump’s wedding dress. Or is it? On Tuesday, a listing surfaced on eBay that claimed to be selling the first lady’s gown, but some details leave its authenticity in question.
  • We’re living in the golden age of gut soda, if there can be such a thing. Brands like Olipop and Poppi that advertise “prebiotic” qualities are seemingly everywhere, and they have gained fans who see them as a better alternative to traditional soda.

M.L.B. Opening Day

Masterpress/Getty Images

A baseball season consists of 30 different soap operas, each lasting six months. Only one ends in true happiness. Here are the top story lines to watch this season.

PLAY A GAME

Wordle →

Connections →

Strands →

And before you go, here’s a quick recommendation

Julia Gartland for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Samantha Seneviratne.

Spring is finally peeking out from behind the cold, dark curtain of winter, which means it’s almost time for all sorts of bright, light food. Here are some recipes you should add to your spring cooking bucket list.

Thanks for spending a few minutes of your morning with The Times. More next week. — Hannah
